ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot of interesting theories, got way better at doing difficult and long academic/old readings, and got better at switching modes of thinking.
Learned about different mediums in art and how they convey emotional meaning.

I learned so much about how to view emotions like anger and compassion from a philosophical perspective and how to understand the meaning of the term pathos and how that applies to the visual arts. I also learned how to form my own perspective on pathos-figures after reading about and integrating so many different perspectives on it throughout the semester.

We read many different theories about transfer of emotion, definitions of passion, transmission of pathos formulae, connections of art to religion. These readings helped develop a framework for thinking about Western art.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Nicola Suthor is so lovely, knowledgeable, and engaging. Class, though, could be confusing and hard to ground in visuals. This class isn't for beginners and I was confused on that.
Fascinating content, however some of the readings were dense and difficult to discuss so some class meetings were dominated by some students and the professor.

Strengths: the readings - although they come from vastly different time periods, they all relate to each other and help us form our own perspective on pathos-figure
Weaknesses: at times, the discussion felt too free-flowing; it would be nice to have more structure in our discussions

Strengths: Really thought-provoking readings; by connecting visual art with broader theories (some of which do not even explicitly mention art), you see how art is connected to the human condition very deeply
Weaknesses: Given so much class time was spent discussing the readings, analyzing actual art pieces sometimes felt like an afterthought

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yep, but it really isn't an intro course so I would suggest some formal background/previous coursework cause it gets really confusing without it sometimes. But the material is great and so is the professor!
Yes! Makes you think about art.
Yes absolutely! However, I would advise the student to take one or two 100 or 200 level art history classes before taking this seminar.
I would recommend it to anyone who wants a survey of Western art history.
